subject: Entrepreneurship
title: Randomized Controlled Trials in Social Impact
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Randomized Controlled Trials in Social Impact.

hook.text: Doctors use randomized trials to test drugs. Two economists decided to test poverty programs the same way.

buildup.text: Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo randomly assigned villages to get aidâ€”or notâ€”and compared results.

discovery.text: They found free bed nets saved far more lives than selling them cheaply. Intuition was dead wrong.

twist.text: Their method killed sacred cows. Microcredit showed disappointing results. Popular programs flopped.

climax.text: Banerjee and Duflo won the 2019 Nobel Prize. Rigorous testing became the gold standard for impact.

punchline.text: The best way to help is to test whether you actually are.

quiz.question: What surprising finding did randomized controlled trials reveal about bed nets?
options: Bed nets were completely ineffective at preventing malaria
Giving bed nets away for free saved far more lives than selling them at low cost
People preferred buying expensive bed nets over receiving free ones
